title: Domain 2.5: Given a scenario, manage and configure basic security settings in the Microsoft Windows OS.
content:
🛡️ Defender Antivirus

  • Activate/Deactivate: Toggle through Windows Security settings to enable/disable protection.
  • Updated Definitions: Keep virus definitions current to detect and block new threats.

🔥 Firewall

  • Activate/Deactivate: Control inbound/outbound traffic — best left ON for protection.
  • Port Security: Restrict specific ports to reduce attack surface.
  • Application Security: Allow/block apps based on behavior or rules.

👥 Users and Groups

  • Local vs. Microsoft Account: Local = device only. Microsoft = sync, recovery, cloud services.
  • Standard Account: Limited rights — safer for daily use.
  • Administrator: Full control over the system.
  • Guest User: Temporary use with minimal access.
  • Power User: More access than standard but not full admin rights.

🔐 Login OS Options

  • Username and Password: Classic login method. Secure if strong password is used.
  • PIN: Short numeric login, device-specific. Works with Windows Hello.
  • Fingerprint: Quick, biometric login method.
  • Facial Recognition: Uses camera to verify user identity. Part of Windows Hello.
  • Single Sign-On (SSO): One login gives access to multiple systems/services.

📁 NTFS vs. Share Permissions

  • File and Folder Attributes: NTFS controls local and network-level file access.
  • Inheritance: Subfolders/files inherit permissions unless overridden.

👨‍💻 Run as Administrator vs. Standard User

  • User Account Control (UAC): Prompts for admin approval to protect against unauthorized changes.

🔐 BitLocker & EFS

  • BitLocker: Encrypts full drive using TPM or USB key — great for laptops.
  • BitLocker To Go: Same as BitLocker but for USB/external drives.
  • EFS: Encrypts individual files/folders tied to user credentials on NTFS volumes.
